localizedDescriptions.en: A framework to communicate information that has been captured and curated in anticipation of future need for care.
Additional composition metadata aligned with IHE-XDS which is not already available from the Reference Model COMPOSITION class.
The code specifying the precise type of document from the user perspective. Normally selected from a valueset provided by the local IHE-XDS Affinity Domain or national standard.

annotations.comment:
for example:  Pulmonary History and Physical, Discharge Summary, Ultrasound Report.
These codes are specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.

localizedDescriptions.en: The ability of an individual to communicate.
Preferred language and/or method of communication for an individual.
A collection of words, their pronunciation and methods for combining them, understood by a specific community and used as a form of communication.
The name of the language.

annotations.comment: For example: Mandarin, Swahili, French or Norwegian sign language. Coding of 'Language' with a terminology is preferred, where possible. ISO 639-3 codes include the simple name of the language but can represent the name and modality combined - for example Norwegian sign language. The value set for codes that are appropriate may depend on the mode.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the specific language capability not captured in other fields.
Identification of an aid to assist communication.

annotations.comment: For example: a hearing aid or tactile reading device. Coding of 'Communication aid' with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Details about the actual communication aid should preferably be recorded using the EVALUATION.device_summary archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: Communication difficulty status
The person has no difficulty communicating.
The person requires the help of an interpreter to communicate.
The person requires the help of aids to communicate.
The person is  unable to communicate
Additional overall narrative about the communication capability of an individual not captured in other fields.
The subject's preferred priorities of care and 'What matters'.
Any other specifc personal request or preference, including cultural or religious preferences.
Any other specifc personal request or preference, including cultural or religious preferences.
Any other specifc personal request or preference, including cultural or religious preferences.
Any other specifc personal request or preference, including cultural or religious preferences.
The patient's preferred place of care (first choice).
The patient's preferred place of care is at home.
The patient's preferred place of care is a hospice.

list.label: Preferred place of care - community hospital

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - community hospital

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a community hospital.
The patient's preferred place of care is a  hospital.

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a nursing home.

list.label: Preferred place of care - residential home

localizedLabels.en: Preferred place of care - residential home

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient's preferred place of care is a residential home.
Details of the organisation/location of the preferred place of care.

localizedNames.en: Preferred place of care (second choice) location details

localizedDescriptions.en: Details of organisation/location of the second choice preference of place of care.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-EVALUATION.care_preference_uk.v0,'Specific preferences']/data[at0001]/items[at0034,'Preferred place of care (second choice) location details']/value

localizedDescriptions.en: The circumstances about an individual living alone or with others.

annotations.comment: This information will provide a sense of the level of support, both physically and emotionally, to which an individual may have access.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word or phrase that describes if an individual usually resides alone or with others.

annotations.comment: Coding of the living arrangement with a terminology is preferred, where possible. The value sets for this data element are likely to vary between jurisdictions - it is anticipated that they will usually be set within a use-case specific template. For example: 'lives alone'; 'lives with family'; or 'lives with others'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word or phrase that describes the relationship between people who reside together.

annotations.comment: Coding of the household composition with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: single; sole parent with children aged less than 16 years; couple; couple with children aged less than 16 years; family; family with other non-related members present; or group of unrelated adults.

localizedDescriptions.en: Contacts for patients and organisations (excluding practitioners).
The relationship between the subject and the contact. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used for patient contacts, not for organisation contacts.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name details aligned with FHIR resource.
Identification of the purpose for the name.
The usual name.
A text representation of the full name.
FHIR telecom details.
Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.
The communication form is phone.
The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
Details of an organisation.
Name of the organisation.
Identifier of organisation.
Additional narrative about the living arrangement not captured in other fields.

children.localizedName: Lasting power of attorney - health and welfare

localizedNames.en: Lasting power of attorney - health and welfare

localizedDescriptions.en: A framework to communicate information about legal directives or orders that apply to the individual, for example, a power of attorney or guardianship order.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-ADMIN_ENTRY.legal_authority.v0,'Lasting power of attorney - health and welfare']

localizedDescriptions.en: The type of legal directive or order that applies to the individual.

annotations.comment: Coding of the type of legal directive or order with a terminology is preferred, where possible. It is expected that this is largely localised to reflect local policy and legislation. For example, 'Welfare Power of Attorney', 'Welfare Guardianship Order' or 'Emergency Detention Order'.

localizedDescriptions.en: A multimedia resource that is generated or acquired during the provision of healthcare.

children.name: Content

localizedDescriptions.en: Digital representation of the resource.

annotations.comment: The actual content will be captured and stored using the Multimedia data type. For example: RTF or PDF for a document; JPG for an image; MP4 for a video; or WAV for an audio file. If the content is stored elsewhere the external location can be referenced using the URI data type.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-ADMIN_ENTRY.legal_authority.v0,'Lasting power of attorney - health and welfare']/data[at0001]/items[at0034]/items[openEHR-EHR-CLUSTER.multimedia_source.v0,'LPA attachment']/items[at0001]/value

localizedDescriptions.en: A framework to communicate the preferences of an individual for future medical treatment and care.
The type of advance care directive.

annotations.comment:
A short text description of the nature of the advance care directive. Coding of the type of directive with a terminology is preferred, where possible. It is expected that this is largely localised to reflect local policy and legislation.

For example, in the Netherlands, advance care directive types include, but are not limited to, 'Treatment prohibition', 'Treatment prohibition with completion of Completed Life', 'Euthanasia request' and 'Declaration of life'.

In the UK, advance care directive types include 'Advance Decision', 'Advance Directive' and 'Advance Statement'.

list.value: Advance Care plan:: 736366004 | Advance care plan (record artifact) |
list.label: Advance Care plan:: 736366004 | Advance care plan (record artifact) |

localizedDescriptions.en: The status of the advance care directive.

annotations.comment: Coding of the advance care directive status with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The individual has an advance care directive.
The individual does not have an advance care directive.
Narrative description of the overall advance care directive.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative overview of the complete advance care directive, which may or may not be supported by structured data. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Directive details' slot. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date when this advance directive record was last updated. This may not be a formal review but e.g. a typo correction.
A framework to communicate the preferences of an individual for future medical treatment and care.
The type of advance care directive.

annotations.comment:
A short text description of the nature of the advance care directive. Coding of the type of directive with a terminology is preferred, where possible. It is expected that this is largely localised to reflect local policy and legislation.

For example, in the Netherlands, advance care directive types include, but are not limited to, 'Treatment prohibition', 'Treatment prohibition with completion of Completed Life', 'Euthanasia request' and 'Declaration of life'.

In the UK, advance care directive types include 'Advance Decision', 'Advance Directive' and 'Advance Statement'.

The individual does not have an advance care directive.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative overview of the complete advance care directive, which may or may not be supported by structured data. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Directive details' slot. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date when this advance directive record was last updated. This may not be a formal review but e.g. a typo correction.
Assessment of the potential and likelihood of future adverse health effects as determined by identified risk factors.
Identification of the potential future disease, condition or health issue for which the risk is being assessed, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of 'Health risk' with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available. For example: risk of cardiovascular disease, with risk factors of hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about each possible risk factor.
Identification of the risk factor, by name.

annotations.comment:
For example: hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia, which may be used as part of the overall assessment for cardiovascular disease; or a genetic marker. Coding of 
'Risk factor' with a terminology, where possible.

list.value: Unable to summon help in an emergency
list.label: Unable to summon help in an emergency

localizedDescriptions.en: Presence of the risk factor.
The risk factor has been identified for this individual.
The risk factor has not been identified for this individual.
Details about each possible risk factor.
Identification of the risk factor, by name.

annotations.comment:
For example: hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia, which may be used as part of the overall assessment for cardiovascular disease; or a genetic marker. Coding of 
'Risk factor' with a terminology, where possible.

list.value: Impaired ability to recognise safety risks
list.label: Impaired ability to recognise safety risks

localizedDescriptions.en: Presence of the risk factor.
The risk factor has been identified for this individual.
The risk factor has not been identified for this individual.
Vision
The ability to move freely, such as changing position, walking and moving forward.
The individual is fully mobile.

The individual is fully or practically immobile.

The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.
